p.seg: When I looked over the Great Repository
the thought occurred to me
on the model of the Comprehensive Catalogue in Honour of Virtue
to select from the various classics the main ideas
and thus to make a Comprehensive Catalogue/Index of the Inner (i.e. Buddhist) Classics.
I considered that whenever they used Indian language in the classics
one had to find the teachings in the classics regarding these.
All the pronunciations and meanings in what was translated I laid out.
I made a separate compilation (Behr reads 冊) of these.
But before I had finished, my illustrious relative Shēn The Elder
showed me the Fānyìmíngyì by the Great Master Pǔrùn from Jǐngdé Monastery in Píngjiāng.
As soon as I saw this I exclaimed in delight:
"This is what I was thinking of.
When some day my Comprehensive Catalogue will be finished
this can be used as an appendix.
After some time I passe by Píngjiāng
and Fǎyún came to visit me.
He was hoping to ask me for an introduction.
I considered this book was not only useful for the reading of Buddhist classics
but that it could also guard against the designs (意根 misused technical term) of those who malign the Dharma of the Buddha.
Dharma Master Xuánzàng of the Táng discussed five failures to translate (properly).
1. Because of secrecy,
as in the case of the (relevant) dhārani.
2. Because of ambiguity
as in the case of bhagavant bógāfàn, which has six meanings.
3. Because the thing in question does not exist (in the target country).
as in the case of the jambu tree.
In China there is in fact no such tree.
Because one follows precedent,
as in the case of anubodhi. ）Anuttara－samyak－saṁbodhi 阿耨多羅三藐三菩提
It is not that this cannot be translated,
but since the time of Mātanga (died 73) there has always been used the Sanskrit sound.
5. Because in its origin it is superior,
as when prajnā has great weight whereas (the Chinese) zhìhuì "mundane wisdom" has little weight and is superficial.

p.seg: The Great Master Pǔrùn
bore the name Fǎyún
and the given name Tiānruì.
He referred to himself as Jīzǐ, and his family name was Gē.
For generations his family was settled in Cǎiyún Village, in Chángzhōu.
His father and mother prayed to the Buddha (were Buddhists).
They dreamt that an Indian monk said:
"I intend to send my spiritual soul to this place."
When Pǔrùn was born, his face resembled the person the parents had dreamt about.
The auspicious signs were extraordinary.
In his swaddles, when the child saw a monk he would be delighted and wanted to go ove to him
as if getting hold of a treasure.
At the age of five (read 歲) he took leave of his parents
in accordace with Buddhist ritual he devoted himself to merciful action, and Pánggōng (whoever he was: unidentified) became his master.
To begin with he followed instruction within the family (so his "taking leave of his parents" is not to be taken too literally)
The sharpness of his spirit was as if it came from the whetstone.
After one year of study he could recite by heart the seven scrolls of the Lotus Sutra.
At the age of nine he underwent tonsure.
At the age of ten be became a novice.
On the basis of the Truths he had received
he went on to ascend the huái-tree seat
and for the assembly he preached the Precepts.
In the fourth year of the sacrifice 禩 of the Shàoshèng era 1097
he set off to visit the regions of the world.
To start with he visited the Dharma Master Tōngzhào
and studied as well as familiarised himself with the practice of the Tiāntái great teaching.
Next he took refuge sitting below the low table of a subtle dharma master of Indian origin
and he duly received the obscure discourse of this man.
In the end, when it came to the knocking and pecking period (of the higher study fo Chán)
he obtained the law from the great Dharma Master Qīngbiàn from Nánpíng (Mountain near Hángzhōu).
In the place of his master he held the rúyì staff
and he held forth for the assembly.
And as a result his name gallopped in all four directions.,
his fame fsoared far into the distance.
Then, in the fourth year of the Zhènghé era
the Academician and Advising Dignitary Yīng Āndào politely invited him to lead the Sōngjiāng Great Enlightenment Monastery.
and Yīng recommended to confer upon him his present appellation,
and the scholars were milling about him like rivers going east.
Throughout all of eight years
Fǎyún comprehensively preached the Lotus Sutra.
the Sutra of the Enlightenment of Golden Light,
the Nirvana Sutra
and other writings of the greater and lesser division (of Buddhist writings).
He continued the days into the night and waited to for the morning (read 旦)
and the shower of generous love poured forth from him.
Then, because his mother was of advanced age
he thought about paying back the generosity of his parents,
so he retired from his job to return to a quiet life at home.
He lived in a hut by the tomb of his ancestors
which he called "Hiding Yún".
Although his living conditions were rough,
still people walking up wearing their straw sandals were many.
They asked him about the Way and they asked him what to do next.
These people were filling up the space outside his door.
He then built (statues of) the Three Sages of the East
and when the statues were set up he converted people over a wide area.
A little later his mother suffered from a slight disease
and the Master Pǔrùn approached the bed where she was resting:
at night he expoundedd to her the Heart Sutra.
When he read out the Amithaba Sutra
the Buddha sent him a golden beam.
His mother reached the stage where she saw everything in all four directions.
This was auspicious and a good omen.
As she approached death she was perfectly contented.
The fiery beam left Buddha-relics behind
and they gleamed like round pearls.
After several days
two dried stems of lotos flowers.
How he conducted h life
one can deduce from this episode.
Using what one is to imitate what one is not
to pass all the way through the Great Meaning
the Way of doing this seems difficult to reach.
And yet the perfect man gets through to the principle of it all
and he reaches everywhere he sets out for.
Thus my Generation-honoured
rose up to the Buddhist Heaven.
He preached the Dharma and repaid the generosity he had received (from his mother).
As a bhikshu with a finger in his hair-bun
he gave everything in his loving conduct.
In the year jiǎzǐ of the shàoxìng era (1144)
the monks of the monastery lead the assembly
and they all went to Yún's humble home
and begged the master to return to the monastery
and to act in accordance with the assembly.
Yún accepted the request.
The next year,
accompanied by his disciples,
he received the statues (of the Three Sages of the East) and entered the monastery.
He opened the Flower Pavillion to make a home for the statues.
On the occasion of the great reunion of the Great Flourishing Lotus
he assembled a thousand men to take classes together and to study the Meditation (Sutra).
He established the Eight Passes Fasting Society.
He established the Eight Passes Fasting Society
as well as the Gold Light Enlightenment (Society)
and the Great Compassion Lotus Enlightenment Diamond Sutra Societies.
At the same time he founded the Fund of Aid from the West.
The dignitaries, the famous intellectuals,
and the four groups of good belieers
lapped up the elevated message of the Master
and the visitors were clogging up the streets.
Some were fighting over who could rush in first
and they overtaking each other up to the last minute.
Such people as Wáng Líng, the jìnshì from Jǐnjiāng
Zhāng Qǐ, the Gòngyuán from Wǔlín,
Wú Yányīng, the State Stipendiate of Sānqū,
Der dēngshì Jīn Tíngguī aus Jiāyāo,
a person Qián from Wúhuì,
alltogether quite a lot of people
were all born again in the Pure Land.
The Dharma Master Fǎyún was widely read in the classics/sutras and in the histories
(his mind) encompassed both the past and the present (history).
He had the talents beyond the ordinary
and he had accumulated in himself the virtuous goodness under ten headings.
He compiled the Fānyìmíngyì.
He wrote a commentary to the Diamond Sutra and a subcommentary to the Heart Sutra,
he authored the Collection on Setting to Rest the Yīn.
All these were famous in the world.
They all glorified the transformation through the sages.
He encouraged the adherents of the Mountain Sect,
and he himself went along to persuade them to change their ways.
What could be done he got finished.
One day he took a bath, changed his clothes
sat down with a straight back, facing West
summoned his disciples and said:
You
should each and every one reflect that the fire of impermanence burns all that is the human worlds,
you should seek to save yourself and quick as you can.
Take care not to be remiss!
And Fǎyún wrote a gāthā:
The qióng tree grows straight up into the clouds,
Still higher than the golden tower;
If there is no more, for one, the land of birth and rebirth,
One moves no more the slightest bit.
If you hold onto this, and onto my testament,
you will reach Buddhist knowledge.
My last request is
that the head of the Hall of Meditation and Wisdom,
the lord of the Dharma of Precious Astonishment
from now on will establish an (ever-burning) torch.
Apart from this there is no other matter."
Having said this he fell silent and was transformed.
That night the sound of the bells were heard far and wide.
Exquisite incense filled the halls.
When they had wrapped him into the shroud
the assembly still heard from the master's mouth how he called out the Buddha'sname, ringing in their ears.
This happened in the 28th yar of the shàoxìng era (1158)
on the 21st day of the ninth month.
He dwelt in this world for 71 years
and he served as a monk for 61 years.
After the fragrant firewood,
there were relics of all sorts.
Ah! How small is the Bóxiè (i.e. Bóhǎi)!
It is insufficient to hold the Wave that overturns emptiness,
how small is the Great Desert!
it is insufficient to spread over it the wings that hang from Heaven!
Today the Dharma Master has the sigh of broad long tongue,
from the Sea of Omniscience
he swirls about whirling upwards in the Heaven of the First Buddhist Truth.
Even the distinguished monks of olden times
did not allow for many of these,
in no time they built a statue for the Dharma Master Fǎyún.
得？？？His disciple the Great Master Wénbiàn
The body of the master went(????) into the the receptable inside the sculpture.????
It turned out that unfortunately the sculpture bore no resemblance,
They had to rework the thing,
so as to display it and burn incense near it.
In fact they desired to make widely known the virtue and goodness of the ancestor (of their school).
His sons and grandsons understood this and passed it on.
In the fifth year of the dàdé era, on xīnchóu, the ninth day of the ninth month
by the acting resident heir,
in the Yǒngdìng Teaching Monsastery,
the Great Master Jíxiáng Xióngbiàn, also called Pǔqià, recorded.
compiled by Fayun, the grandmaster Purun (‘Omnibenefactor’) from Jingde-monastery at the Gusu [-mountain] under the Song.
“To ‘translate’ (fanyi)
means to turn over (fan) words of the brahmaloka (i.e. Indian words)
and to transform them into the language of the Han territories.
Even if the sounds are seemingly different,
meanings by and large correspond.
In the Biographies of [Eminent] monks compiled under the [Great] Song it is said:
‘It is like turning over a brocade embroidery: front and back are both gorgeous,
but left and right are reversed.’
“To ‘translate’ something means to ‘exchange’
i.e. ‘to exchange what one does have
for what one does not’.
That is why using the canonical scriptures of one place
one makes illustrious the teachings (fa, dharma) of another country.”
[According to] the Zhouli (Etiquette of the Zhou), “there are separate offices in charge of the languages of the four quarters.
The one for the east is called ji (‘to confide’),
the one for the south is called xiang
(‘to represent’), the one for the west is called didi (?‘convey knwoledge’)
and the one for the north is called yi (‘to translate’).”1
The reason for the fact that even those who understand the languages of the west are called ‘translators’ (yi) today
is probably that the period of the Han was predominantly concerned with the northern territories
and the yi-translator-officials were well-versed in the western languages as well.
For this reason, Mo-teng [Kāśyapa] Mātaṅga), when he arrived as the first [translator]
and translated the Si-shi’er zhang jing (The sūtra in 42 sections),
was called ‘yi’ (-translator).
We speak of ming and yi,
because ‘what can [be used to] gloss something’ is called ming (‘terms’)
and it is by means of this that one constitutes yi (‘meaning’).
The terms which can be glossed,
are different in sound among the Hu (Central Asian peoples) and the Fan (Indians).
From Han (206 v. Chr. - 220 n. Chr.) to Sui (581-618) times,
the western territories were unanimously referred to as ‘Hu-contries’.
During the Tang (618-907) it was master-of-the-dharma Yancong alone,
who differentiated between Hu and Fan.
All territories to the west of the Congling-range (i.e. the Pamir mountains)
belong to the race of the Fan,
all to the south of Tiemen (‘Irongate’)
are called ‘Home of the Hu’.
To speak of fan-sounds,
because in the beginning of this cosmic age (kalpa), when everything was vacant,
the heavenly spirit of light and sound descended as the ancestor of men,
[and] propagated and diffused the fan-sounds.
Therefore the Xiyu ji (Records from the western territories) says:
"Describing the words/characters of their language in detail,
[it is to be noticed, that] they were created by God Brahman.
The rules originally handed down to us
fix 47 letters,
through which the [representations of] the myriad things are combinatorily produced.
Over time, various different usages [of this syllabary]
have come into being,
its original spring inundated a wide region
and — depending on the people who spoke it in the four lands — there have been slight [linguistic] changes.
But speaking of [the language‘s] major principles,
they do not differ from the original source,
and in Central India
it is especially differenciated and correct.
Intonation of the words is harmoniuous and elegant,
corresponding to the sounds of the heaven.
Its prosody ist clear and bright,
cultivation towards cutting off [the samsara] will be blocked.”
I have been asked sometimes:
“After Tripiṭaka Xuanzang and the master-of-the-dharma Yijing
had travelled through the Fan countries in the West
and translated [the texts acquired] into Chinese in the East,
they pointed at the antique translations available
and corrected old mistakes.
But how is it conceivable that those who conveyed [the texts of] Nāgārjuna in the beginning would have discussed the fan (Sanskrit) sounds without being familiar with them?
(For instance, when they (the antique translators) transcribe (the Sanskrit word for) ‘vulture’ as qi-she ,
(the Sanskrit word for) ‘head’ as jue,
Xuanzang says: ‘This is mistaken,
[deleting anaptyctic vowels], it should now be rendered as jie-li-luo-ju-zha.)
Or when [Kumā]rajīva, the one adorned with the threefold wisdom, would have been in-correct when translating into the language of the [later] Qin (383-417)?!
([Kumāra]jīva translated (the word transcribed as) luo-hou-luo with ‘covered’,
[Xuan]zang tanslated (the word transcribed as) luo-hu-luo with ‘seizer of the sun’.)
If all of these [translations] was erroneous,
how could an intuitive understanding have been reached,
of which we have profitted from antiquity to the present age and whose rich blessings have appeared from the dark?”
Now I will try to explain it like this:
In the states of Qin and Chu [during Zhou times]
there were the different designations bi (OC *p-rut) and yu (*ɢ-rut) (for ‘writing-brush’),
and during Yin and Xia times
cultural patterns were substantially different.
How much more then will the five [regions of] India have differed?
A millenium is a long time indeed, times and customs are constantly transformed,
languages change and designations shift.
And when it came to the new traditions of Liang- and Tang- times,
they then were different from the old translations of the [later] Qin and Jin periods again.
[Considering all this], why should — if only the meaning is comprehensible —
these [translation] terms be suppressed?
‘Even if the weir-baskets used are not the same,
how would the fish caught by them differ?’3
At the age of ten years, [I,] Fayun was without knowledge,
wearing the ‘three garments’ promiscuously.
Afterwards I studied the holy teachings,
but did not have a clue about the language of the Fan (i.e. Sanskrit).
Therefore I thought about meanings and categories,
making myself a notice whenever I saw one of them.
But the commentaries to the sūtras are scattered
and the meanings recorded in abhidharma literature are very broad.
In the course of my work I made additions and deletions,
for almost two decades by now.
These I compiled into [a book of] seven fascicles and sixty-four chapters.
Even the ‘ten titles’ and the ‘three bodies’
are now to be found in the index,
and the ‘four continents’ and ‘seven paths’
have been elucidated and so become tangible.
One is spared the effort of having to search through [the canonical texts]
and the beauty of the actual references
has been assigned its proper place.
But I am ashamed that the ‘heavens of meaning’ are getting wider, [too wide, to] complete my limited view of it.
The sea of the teaching is dark and deep —
how could it be possible to exhaust it with a calabash?
All shortcomings and doubts of it (i.e. my book),
are bequeathed to the universally intelligent of a coming age …
In the thirteenth year of the shaoxing reign under the great Song (1143),
the cyclical year is guihai,
on the last day of the mid-autumn month,
in the mi-tuo amitā[bha] ) hall,
ailing …
